rationale: Represents a specific subset of body language (communication mode) related to romance, distinct from individual behaviors or emotional states.
Denotes a specific physical behavior (touching) rather than the broader category of romantic body language or the resulting emotional states.
Captures a distinct physical behavior (gazing) as a nonverbal signal, not interchangeable with touching or mirroring gestures.
Refers to a specific behavior (mirroring gestures) that is conceptually separate from other listed behaviors and states.
Represents an emotional state (attraction) that is an outcome signaled by behaviors, not the behaviors themselves.
Defines a social/relational state (intimacy) distinct from both the signaling behaviors and the emotional state of attraction.
All four entities refer to the same general concept of posture as a body position used in body language and nonverbal communication, with overlapping definitions and context.
"Good posture" is a more specific subtype emphasizing upright, aligned body position to convey confidence and authority, so it should remain distinct from the general concept of posture.
All four 'gestures' mentions refer to the same concept of body movements used in nonverbal communication, differing only in type labels but not in meaning.
Refers specifically to the action 'waving hello', a distinct gesture type, not the general concept of gestures.
Refers specifically to the 'thumbs up' gesture, which is a particular example rather than the general category of gestures.
Denotes 'messages' as the abstract information conveyed, conceptually distinct from the physical acts of gesturing.
Both refer to the same nonverbal behavior of looking into another’s eyes; one is the general term and the other a phrasing of sustained use of it in conversation.
Avoiding eye contact is a distinct behavior (the deliberate lack of eye contact), not just a variant label of eye contact itself.
Engagement here is a mental/social state signaled by eye contact, conceptually separate from the behavior of eye contact itself.
Attentiveness is a distinct positive cognitive/attentional state, clearly different from discomfort and dishonesty.
Discomfort is a separate negative affective state and is not semantically equivalent to attentiveness or dishonesty.
Dishonesty refers to lack of truthfulness, a distinct moral/behavioral state, and should remain separate from attentiveness and discomfort.
Both entities describe the same head movement used in communication, differing only slightly in wording and type_hint, so they should be merged into a single gesture concept.
This refers specifically to the arm-folding gesture and is distinct from emotional or cognitive states and from nodding.
Defensiveness is an emotional/psychological state and not redundant with any other entity in the group.
Discomfort is a distinct emotional state, separate from defensiveness, agreement, and understanding.
Agreement is a specific cognitive/social state and is not equivalent to understanding or any gesture.
Understanding is a cognitive state distinct from agreement and the various gestures mentioned.
All three refer to the same general concept of facial expressions as nonverbal communicative cues, differing only in wording and type granularity.
These all describe the same facial expression (smile/smiles/smiling) with consistent semantics, differing only by form (singular, plural, gerund) and minor type-labeling.
Frowns are a distinct facial expression type and should remain separate from smiles and general facial expressions.
Raised eyebrows denote a specific facial expression type distinct from smiles and generic facial expressions.
Happiness is an internal emotional state, not a facial movement, and should not be merged with expression entities.
Friendliness is an emotional or attitudinal state conceptually distinct from the facial expressions that may signal it.
Refers to a specific facial expression (a physical phenomenon), distinct from the emotional states it may signal.
Represents the emotion/state of confusion, conceptually different from both concern and the facial expression that may indicate it.
Represents the emotion/state of concern, which is distinct from confusion and from the facial expression (furrowed brow) that may signal it.
All mentions refer to the same abstract concept of underlying plans or purposes inferred from body language in the same discourse context, differing only slightly in wording and type granularity.
All mentions refer to the same concept of internal affective states conveyed via body language; type_hint differences are minor refinements of the same psychological construct.
All four mentions share the same name and consistently describe interpersonal exchanges shaped by body language in social contexts, differing only slightly in wording.
“Various situations” refers broadly to different contexts for using body language, not specifically to interpersonal exchanges, so it should remain distinct.
“Social situations” denotes contextual environments where people interact, which is related to but not identical with the process of social interaction itself.
“Social settings” emphasizes general social environments and is separate from the process-level concept of interactions.
“Meaningful interactions” focuses on depth and significance of exchanges, a distinct nuanced concept from generic social interactions.
“Fulfilling interactions” emphasizes satisfaction and fulfillment, which is conceptually different from merely meaningful or generic social interactions.
“Others” represents the people with whom one interacts, an agent role rather than an interaction or context, so it should remain separate.
Refers specifically to small nonverbal signals; distinct, coherent concept not duplicated elsewhere in the group.
Represents a cognitive state (comprehension of others) rather than the cues themselves; conceptually different from 'subtle cues'.
Refers to the specific physical spacing between people in an interaction, distinct from the broader concept or field studying it.
Refers to the concept/field of proxemics (study/use of interpersonal distance), not just a particular instance of distance.
Represents culturally derived signals, which are conceptually distinct from personal/individual cues and from proxemics as a field.
Represents individual-specific signals in interaction, distinct from broad cultural cues and the concept of proxemics.
This refers to a specific written work (a document) about body language, distinct from conceptual categories of body language.
This refers to the conceptual categories or forms of body language, not to the essay itself, so it should remain a separate concept entity.
Refers to the general process of conveying information or feelings, not tied to a specific modality.
Refers specifically to a modality (a form of communication, here body language) rather than the overall process of communication, so it should remain distinct.
Represents a specific qualitative aspect of communication (clarity), distinct from effectiveness and other entities.
Represents a different qualitative aspect of communication (effectiveness), not identical to clarity or to general communication.
Denotes the overall process of communication, conceptually broader than specific qualities or skills.
Refers to a capability (communication skills), which is distinct from the process of communication and its qualitative attributes.
This refers to a specific posture pattern distinct from emotional or personality traits, so it should remain a separate entity.
Confidence is an emotional/psychological state, conceptually separate from both posture and assertiveness, so it should be kept distinct.
Assertiveness is a behavioral trait different from both the specific posture and the emotional state of confidence, so it should remain its own entity.
Refers to a specific posture pattern (slouching), distinct from emotional states; description and type_hint are consistent.
Represents an emotional state (insecurity) that is conceptually different from posture; no conflicting evidence to justify merging or modification.
Represents a separate emotional state (disinterest), distinct from both slouching and insecurity; type and description are appropriate.

All these mentions define body language as the same general nonverbal communication system using posture, gestures, facial expressions, and related cues, differing only in wording or minor type emphasis.
This refers specifically to the routine, everyday behavioral use of body language, which is a distinct concept from the general phenomenon itself.
This captures the particular behavior of using body language to convey emotions, a specific application rather than the general concept of body language.
This focuses on the nonverbal signals sent through body language, i.e., the signal type, which is more specific than the overall communication mode.
This denotes the skill or mastery ('art') of using and interpreting body language, conceptually distinct from body language as a communication system.
Refers to the broad process of communication without words; distinct from specific modes (body language) or signals (nonverbal cues).
Represents body language as a specific form/mode of nonverbal communication, not identical to the broader process or to individual cues.
Captures nonverbal cues as individual signals rather than the overall mode (body language) or process (nonverbal communication).
Represents research activity on nonverbal communication, distinct from the communication process and from specific findings.
Represents a particular class of research findings (percent of communication via body language), more specific than general research activity.
All three are the same term 'rapport' in identical body-language contexts, described as a harmonious, attentive social state.
Both use the plural term 'connections' to denote interpersonal bonds enhanced by body language in similar social contexts.
All three refer to the same plural concept 'relationships' as ongoing social/emotional ties affected by body language; type hints differ only slightly in granularity.
Distinct interaction behavior describing the act of mirroring posture, not a social state or relationship concept.
Refers specifically to a subjective 'sense of connection', which is conceptually narrower than general 'connections' and may warrant separate representation.
Represents the distinct social process of forming or enhancing social bonds, which is separate from conflict resolution and the outcome of stronger relationships.
Clearly denotes the specific process of resolving disagreements, which is conceptually different from general connection and relationship quality.
Refers to the outcome state of having more resilient, positive relationships, not the processes that lead to it, so it should remain separate.
Both mentions refer to the same emotional/psychological concept of self-assured confidence expressed via body language, differing only in contextual framing.
This represents the general concept of posture as a body-language component, distinct from specific posture patterns or emotional states.
This is a specific posture pattern (upright, shoulders back), not a general posture concept or emotional state.
This is a specific posture pattern (slouching), distinct from other posture concepts and emotional states.
This refers to assertiveness as a behavioral trait, conceptually different from confidence and posture itself.
This refers to insecurity as an emotional state, distinct from confidence and other traits.
This refers to disinterest as an emotional/attentional state, distinct from other emotions and traits mentioned.
This is authority as a social role attribute, not an emotional state or posture pattern.
This is the concept of good posture as a physical behavior, broader than and distinct from the specific pattern 'standing up straight with shoulders back'.
Represents a distinct category of nonverbal communication (romantic body language), not synonymous with any of the specific behaviors or emotional states.
Denotes a specific physical behavior (touching) that is a component of romantic body language, distinct from gazing, mirroring, attraction, or intimacy.
Represents a specific nonverbal behavior (gazing) distinct from touching, mirroring gestures, and the broader concepts of attraction or intimacy.
Refers to a specific behavior (mirroring gestures) and is not interchangeable with touching, gazing, or the emotional/social states mentioned.
Describes an emotional state (attraction) that is conceptually distinct from the behaviors that signal it and from intimacy.
Represents a social/relational state (intimacy) different from romantic body language and its specific behavioral components.
Refers specifically to the process of interpersonal exchanges, which is distinct from contextual environments or situations.
Represents a broad set of different contexts or circumstances, not limited to social environments, so it should remain separate.
Both describe essentially the same concept of social environments where people interact, differing only slightly in wording and granularity.
Refers to general interpersonal bonds in plural form, distinct from the subjective feeling described by 'sense of connection'.
Denotes a specific interaction behavior (posture mirroring), not a social state, so it should remain a separate entity.
Refers to the subjective feeling of closeness, which is conceptually different from general 'connections' and should not be merged.
Represents the social process of forming connections, distinct from outcomes or qualities of relationships.
Represents the quality/outcome of relationships, which is conceptually different from the act of connecting with others.
Represents the distinct concept of interactions characterized by depth or significance, which is related to but not identical with fulfillment.
Represents the distinct concept of interactions that provide satisfaction or fulfillment; although co-mentioned with meaningful interactions, the terms are not strictly synonymous.
Represents the general concept of gestures in nonverbal communication, distinct from specific example gestures or abstract messages.
Refers to a specific hand gesture (waving hello) as a particular action, not the general category of gestures.
Represents another specific hand gesture (thumbs up) that is distinct from both the general concept of gestures and other example gestures.
Denotes the abstract concept of messages or meanings conveyed by gestures, which is conceptually different from gestures themselves and particular gesture actions.
The current description includes meta-commentary about merging; this trims it to a clean, concept-focused definition without changing the meaning.
This is a distinct gesture (arms folded across the torso) and does not overlap with any other entity in the group.
Defensiveness is a distinct emotional state and is clearly differentiated from other cognitive or emotional states here.
Discomfort is a separate emotional state from defensiveness and agreement/understanding, so it should remain distinct.
Agreement is a specific cognitive/social state distinct from understanding and the emotional states; no duplicate exists.
Understanding is a distinct cognitive state separate from agreement and the emotional states, with no overlapping entity to merge.
Refers specifically to nonverbal signals (facial expressions, gestures, posture), a distinct phenomenon from the cognitive state of understanding others.
Describes a cognitive state (comprehension of other people’s states and intentions), which is conceptually different from the external nonverbal cues themselves.
Represents the specific phenomenon (interpersonal distance) related to but distinct from the broader concept/field of proxemics; type refined from OperatingCondition to Concept.
Refers to the established concept/field of proxemics, distinct from the specific phenomenon of interpersonal distance.
Cultural cues are a separate concept describing signals from cultural norms, not the same as distance or proxemics as a field.
Personal cues are individual-specific signals and conceptually distinct from proxemics and interpersonal distance.
A specific nonverbal behavior distinct from emotional or moral states; no overlap with others.
A cognitive/attentional state different from discomfort and dishonesty; only contextually related via eye contact.
An emotional state distinct from attentiveness and dishonesty; no evidence they refer to the same concept.
A moral/behavioral trait (lack of truthfulness) distinct from discomfort and attentiveness; should remain separate.
Represents the specific nonverbal behavior of looking into another’s eyes; distinct from the broader interaction state of engagement.
Represents a general state of involvement/participation in interaction, which is only signaled by but not identical to eye contact.
Both entities share the same name, type, and closely aligned descriptions of the general process of conveying information, including nonverbal aspects.
Represents a specific quality (clarity) of communication, distinct from the general process and other qualities.
Represents a specific quality (effectiveness) of communication, distinct from clarity and from the general process.
Refers to a mode/form of communication (specifically body language), which is conceptually distinct from the general process of communication.
Denotes a capability (communication skills), which is different from both the process of communication and its qualities or modes.
Refers to the general class of facial expressions as nonverbal cues, distinct from specific expressions like smiles or frowns.
Refers specifically to the facial expression 'smile', which is a distinct concept from general facial expressions and from frowns.
Refers specifically to 'frowns', a distinct facial expression with different emotional valence from smiles and from the broad category of facial expressions.
Refers to the overall process of nonverbal communication, distinct from cues, research activities, or specific findings.
Represents individual nonverbal signals (cues), which are conceptually separate from the broader process and from research about them.
Denotes the activity of conducting research on nonverbal communication, not the communication itself or specific empirical estimates.
Captures a specific class of research findings about the proportion of communication via body language, which is more specific than general research and should remain separate.
Represents the distinct emotional state of confusion, which is not equivalent to concern even though both can be signaled by a furrowed brow.
Represents the distinct emotional state of concern (worry/care), which is semantically different from confusion and should remain separate.
Represents a specific written work (a document) about body language, distinct from the conceptual categories it discusses.
Represents the conceptual categories or forms of body language, not the essay itself; therefore it should remain a separate concept entity.
Refers specifically to the emotional state of happiness; distinct concept from friendliness even though both can be signaled by a smile.
Refers to the emotional/attitudinal state of friendliness, which is conceptually different from happiness and should remain a separate entity.
Refers specifically to the facial expression of lifting the eyebrows, distinct from a furrowed brow.
Refers specifically to the facial expression involving wrinkling the forehead, distinct from raised eyebrows.
Represents the general concept of body language as a communication system, distinct from any particular usage pattern.
Refers specifically to the habitual, everyday use of body language, which is conceptually different from the abstract concept of body language itself.
Refers specifically to the behavioral use of body language to express emotions, which is narrower than general mastery and should remain distinct.
Refers to the broader skill/art of using and interpreting body language overall, not limited to conveying emotions, so it should not be merged with the more specific behavior entity.
Refers to the general concept of body language as a communication mode, distinct from specific signals conveyed through it.
Refers specifically to individual nonverbal signals expressed via body language, which is a related but more granular concept than body language itself.
Refers to the general class of facial expressions as nonverbal cues, distinct from specific expressions or internal emotional states.
Represents the broad concept of internal affective states, which is more general than any specific emotion listed and not a duplicate of other entities.
Denotes a specific facial expression (smile) distinct from other expressions and broader categories like facial expressions or emotions.
Represents a specific type of facial expression (frowns) separate from smiles and other listed expressions.
Represents a distinct facial expression (raised eyebrows), not redundant with other entities.
Denotes a specific facial expression (furrowed brow) with its own associated meanings, distinct from other expressions.
A specific positive emotional state (happiness), not equivalent to the general category 'emotions' or to other specific emotions.
Represents a particular emotional/attitudinal state (friendliness) distinct from other emotions like happiness or concern.
Denotes a specific cognitive-emotional state (confusion), distinct from other emotional states in the list.
Represents a particular emotional state (concern) that is not redundant with any other entity here.
Refers specifically to the subset of body language associated with romantic interest, distinct from the individual behaviors it includes.
Represents a specific physical behavior (touching) used as a romantic signal, not identical to other behaviors or the broader category of romantic body language.
Denotes a particular behavior (gazing) that is distinct from touching, mirroring, and the broader category of romantic body language.
Refers to mirroring gestures as a specific nonverbal behavior and is conceptually separate from other behaviors and emotional states.
Represents the emotional state of attraction, which is distinct from the behaviors that signal it and from intimacy.
Captures the social/relational state of intimacy, which is different from attraction and from the nonverbal behaviors that indicate it.
Refers generally to interpersonal social bonds in plural form; distinct from the subjective feeling or specific behaviors.
A concrete interaction behavior (posture mirroring), not a social state; should remain a separate entity.
Represents a subjective social state (feeling of connection), conceptually distinct from general 'connections' and from the mirroring behavior.
Represents social environments/contexts, which is conceptually distinct from the events/processes of interaction even though related.
Represents the processes or exchanges between people, not the contexts themselves, so it should remain a separate entity from social situations.
Represents the process of forming or enhancing social bonds, distinct as an activity rather than an outcome.
Represents the resulting state or outcome (more resilient relationships), which is conceptually different from the process of connecting with others.
Represents the distinct concept of interactions characterized by depth and significance, which is semantically different from interactions characterized by fulfillment or satisfaction.

Represents the concept of interactions that provide satisfaction or fulfillment; although mentioned in the same phrase as 'meaningful interactions', it is a related but not identical social-process concept.
Represents a specific head-movement gesture (nodding) distinct from other gestures or states mentioned.
Represents a distinct physical gesture (crossing one's arms) separate from the emotional or cognitive states it may signal.
Represents an emotional/psychological state (defensiveness) distinct from both gestures and other states like discomfort.
Represents a distinct emotional state (discomfort) separate from defensiveness and from gestures.
Represents a cognitive/social state (agreement) distinct from understanding and from any gestures.
Represents a cognitive state (understanding) that is conceptually different from agreement and the gestures mentioned.
Both entities describe the same nonverbal behavior of looking directly into another person's eyes, differing only in phrasing and granularity, so they should be unified.
Avoiding eye contact is a distinct behavior from making eye contact, representing deliberate non-gaze rather than gaze.
Attentiveness is a mental/state concept inferred from behavior, not the behavior of eye contact itself.
Engagement is a separate state of involvement, only signaled by eye contact but not identical to it.
Discomfort is an emotional/mental state that may be inferred from behavior but is conceptually distinct.
Dishonesty is a moral/behavioral state separate from nonverbal cues like eye contact avoidance.
Represents the concrete nonverbal body movements themselves, distinct from the information they convey.
Represents the abstract information or meanings conveyed by gestures, which is conceptually separate from the gestures as physical actions.
Refers specifically to the greeting gesture of waving hello, distinct from other gestures.
Refers specifically to the thumbs up gesture, which is a different action from waving hello.
Represents the distinct emotional state of confidence; no other entity in the group refers to the same general concept.
A specific posture pattern (upright with shoulders back) distinct from emotional states and other posture types.
A distinct posture pattern (slouching) not equivalent to the upright posture or any emotional trait.
Assertiveness is a separate behavioral trait from confidence and the various postures mentioned.
Insecurity is a distinct emotional state, not safely mergeable with confidence or disinterest.
Disinterest is a separate emotional/attentional state, distinct from insecurity and confidence.
Distinct concept referring to work-related or career-oriented environments; no overlapping identity with the other entity.
Represents a social role attribute (perceived power/leadership) and is conceptually different from a professional context; should remain separate.
Represents the general concept of posture as a body-language component, distinct from specific qualitative variants like good or bad posture.
Refers specifically to a positive, upright form of posture used to convey confidence, which is a subtype/specific instance rather than the same concept as generic posture.
Refers broadly to small nonverbal signals; not clearly identical to the more specific cultural or personal cues entities.
Specifically about signals derived from cultural norms; distinct from general subtle cues and from individual-specific personal cues.
Specifically about individual-specific signals; distinct from general subtle cues and from culture-level cues.
Represents the phenomenon of physical spacing between people, which is conceptually distinct from the broader field that studies it.
Represents the academic/analytic concept (the study of interpersonal distance), not the distance itself, so it should remain a separate entity.
Represents the general process of conveying information, distinct from specific modalities or forms.
Refers to a specific modality (a form of communication, here body language), which is conceptually narrower than the general process of communication and should remain distinct.
Represents a specific quality (clarity of communication) distinct from other communication-related concepts.
Represents a separate quality (effectiveness of communication) that is related to but not identical with clarity of communication.
Denotes a broader capability (communication skills), not just a single quality, so it should remain distinct from clarity/effectiveness entities.
Distinct document entity referring to a specific essay; not a concept or situation like the others.
Clearly a separate conceptual entity about categories of body language, not the essay itself or particular situations.
Refers to contextual situations in which body language is used; distinct from the essay and from the concept of body language types.
Represents the general concept/system of body language as a communication mode, distinct from specific usages or behaviors.
Describes a specific behavioral pattern (everyday habitual use of body language), not the abstract system itself, so it should remain separate.
Refers to a particular use case/behavior (using body language specifically to convey emotions), which is narrower than and distinct from the general concept.
Nonverbal communication is a broader process category that includes multiple channels (e.g., body language, eye contact, proxemics), so it should remain distinct.
Body language is a specific mode/channel of nonverbal communication, not identical to the broader concept, so it should be kept as a separate entity.
Represents the concept of nonverbal signals themselves, distinct from research activities or specific findings.
Refers to the body of empirical research on nonverbal communication, a different concept from the cues or particular estimates.
Captures specific research findings estimating body-language proportions, which is more granular than the general research activity.
Interpersonal distance is a distinct concept (the physical spacing itself), not the same as proxemics (the study of such spacing).
Proxemics correctly refers to the study/use of interpersonal distance, which is conceptually distinct from the distance itself and from the cues it conveys.
Cultural cues are distinct from both interpersonal distance and proxemics, and also distinct from personal (individual) cues.
Personal cues represent individual-specific signals and are conceptually distinct from cultural cues and proxemics-related concepts.
Represents the general nonverbal behavior of eye contact; no other entity refers to the exact same behavior concept.
Represents a distinct, opposite behavior (avoiding eye contact) rather than the general behavior of eye contact.
Denotes a mental/attentional state (attentiveness), not a behavior; distinct semantic type from the others.
Represents engagement as a state of involvement, conceptually distinct from both eye behaviors and other states.
Captures the emotional/physical state of discomfort, which is not synonymous with any other listed entity.
Describes the moral/behavioral trait of dishonesty, distinct from attentiveness, engagement, discomfort, and eye behaviors.
Represents the general concept of gestures as nonverbal cues; no other entity in the group refers to this broad category.
Refers specifically to the gesture of nodding, distinct from the general concept of gestures and other specific gestures mentioned.
Denotes the specific hand gesture of waving hello used as a greeting, which is distinct from nodding and from the generic category of gestures.
Represents the specific thumbs up hand gesture indicating approval, distinct from waving hello, nodding, and the general gestures concept.
Represents the abstract concept of messages or meanings conveyed, which is conceptually different from any concrete gesture entity.
Refers to the general concept of facial expressions as nonverbal cues; no other entity represents this same broad category.
Denotes the general class of internal affective states (emotions), distinct from any specific emotion listed.

Refers specifically to 'frowns' as a facial expression, distinct from smiles or other configurations.

Refers specifically to 'furrowed brow' as a distinct facial expression associated with certain states.

Refers to the social/romantic state of intimacy, which is conceptually different from the concrete behavior of touching.

Represents the behavioral trait of assertiveness, which is related to but not identical with confidence.

Describes a person’s comprehension of others, which is a different concept from the nonverbal cues that inform that understanding.

Represents a broader set of abilities in communication, not just clarity or effectiveness of a specific interaction.

Refers to the contextual environment of social life, distinct from specific interactions or states like rapport.
Represents the process of exchanges between people, which is conceptually different from contexts (situations) or social states.

Represents interactions that provide satisfaction or fulfillment, which is related to but not identical to meaningful interactions in the source text.

Represents the result or state of having resilient and positive interpersonal connections, which is conceptually different from the process of connecting.
Although closely related in context, 'meaningful interactions' emphasizes depth and significance, which is conceptually distinct from fulfillment or satisfaction.
‘Fulfilling interactions’ focuses on personal satisfaction or a sense of fulfillment, which is related to but not identical with meaningful interactions, so they should not be merged.
Refers to observable nonverbal facial movements, distinct from internal psychological states.
Refers to internal affective psychological states, not the external facial cues used to express them.
Distinct concept describing a category of nonverbal communication (romantic body language) rather than a specific behavior or emotional state.
Refers specifically to physical touching as a behavior, which is narrower than and not identical to the broader concept of romantic body language.
Represents gazing as a specific physical behavior, distinct from other behaviors and from emotional or social states.
Captures mirroring gestures as a particular nonverbal behavior, which is not interchangeable with the other entities.
Models attraction as an emotional state, conceptually different from body language behaviors and social closeness.
Represents intimacy as a social/relational state, distinct from both specific behaviors and the emotional state of attraction.
Represents the specific facial expression 'smile', distinct in form and meaning from 'frowns'.
Represents the facial expression 'frowns', which is semantically different from 'smile' and should remain a separate entity.
Happiness is a distinct positive emotional state and is conceptually different from friendliness.
Friendliness refers to a warm, approachable attitude, which is related to but distinct from happiness.
Confusion and concern are distinct emotional states and are separately described; no evidence they refer to the same canonical entity.
Concern is a different emotion from confusion, both semantically and in the given descriptions, so it should remain a separate entity.
Represents a specific facial expression (raised eyebrows) distinct from other expressions like a furrowed brow.
Represents a different facial expression (furrowed brow) with its own meaning and usage; should not be merged with raised eyebrows.
Represents nonverbal signals themselves, distinct from any cognitive state or understanding derived from them.
Represents a cognitive state (comprehension of others) that is conceptually different from the nonverbal cues that inform it, so it should remain separate.
Interpersonal distance is a distinct concept (the actual spacing between people), not the same as proxemics (the study/use of that spacing).
Proxemics is correctly defined as the study/use of interpersonal distance and should remain separate from the distance itself and from cue types.
Cultural cues are distinct from personal cues and proxemics as a domain; they represent signals derived from shared cultural norms.
Personal cues are individual-specific signals and conceptually different from cultural cues, proxemics, and interpersonal distance.
Refers specifically to the nonverbal behavior of making eye contact; no other entity in the group denotes the same concept.
Denotes the distinct behavior of deliberately not making eye contact, which is conceptually different from eye contact itself.
Represents a mental state (attentiveness) that can be inferred from behavior but is not itself a behavior, so it should remain separate.
Describes a state of involvement/participation (engagement), distinct from the other listed states and behaviors.
Captures the emotional state of discomfort, which is a separate concept from attentiveness, engagement, and dishonesty.
Refers to lack of truthfulness (dishonesty), a distinct conceptual state from the others and not redundant with any entity here.
Represents the general process of nonverbal communication, distinct from specific cues or research about it.
Represents individual nonverbal signals (cues), which are a different concept from the overall process of nonverbal communication.
Represents research activity about nonverbal communication, which is conceptually distinct from the communication process and the cues themselves.
Represents a specific subset of research findings (studies estimating body-language proportion), not the same as the broader research activity entity.
Represents the general process of communication, distinct from a specific modality or form.
Refers specifically to a modality (body language) as a form of communication, not the overall process; should remain separate.
Represents a specific quality dimension (clarity) of communication distinct from other communication aspects.
Represents a separate quality dimension (effectiveness) of communication, not guaranteed identical to clarity.
Refers to an ability/capability (skills) rather than a quality metric, so should remain distinct from the quality entities.
Represents the general concept of gestures as nonverbal body movements; no other entity in the group denotes this same broad category.
Refers specifically to the gesture of nodding, distinct from the more general 'gestures' concept and from other specific gestures like waving or thumbs up.
Denotes the specific hand gesture 'waving hello', which is a distinct instance of a gesture and not a duplicate of any other entity.
Refers to the specific 'thumbs up' hand gesture, conceptually separate from nodding, waving, or the general category of gestures.
Represents the abstract concept of 'messages' conveyed via gestures, which is semantically distinct from the gestures themselves.
A distinct gesture concept (crossing arms) separate from the emotional or cognitive states it may signal.
Defensiveness is an emotional state, not identical to the gesture or other states mentioned.
Discomfort is a separate emotional state from defensiveness and the gesture itself.
Agreement is a distinct cognitive/social state, not the same as understanding or the signaling gesture.
Understanding is a separate cognitive state from agreement, even if both can be signaled by nodding.
Refers to the communication mode of body language as a specific form of nonverbal communication, distinct from mental states like intentions.
Refers to the abstract cognitive state of intentions, which is conceptually different from the communication mode of body language.
Represents a specific written document (an essay), distinct from the abstract concept of types of body language.
Represents a conceptual category (forms of body language), not a document, so it should remain separate from the essay entity.
Represents general, routine body language use in daily life, which is broader than specific emotional expression.
Focuses specifically on using body language to convey emotions, a subset of overall daily body language use, so it should remain distinct.
Refers to the nonverbal signals themselves (a type of signal), distinct from the skill of using or interpreting them.
Refers to the skill/art of body language, which is conceptually different from the signals that are sent through body language.
